description: From Middle English ascriben, from Old French ascrivre (“inscribe, attribute, impute”), from Latin āscrībere (“to state in writing”), equivalent to a- +‎ scribe.

verbs.description: ascribe (third-person singular simple present ascribes, present participle ascribing, simple past and past participle ascribed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To attribute a cause or characteristic to someone or something.
examples: One may ascribe these problems to the federal government; however, at this stage it is unclear what caused them.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To attribute a book, painting or any work of art or literature to a writer or creator.
examples: It is arguable as to whether we can truly ascribe this play to Shakespeare.

entries.meaning: (nonstandard, with to) To believe in or agree with; subscribe.
